sec.title: Objective
sec.p: People diagnosed with brain cancer commonly present to the emergency department (ED). There is uncertainty about essential components and processes of optimal care from the perspective of consumers, and few guidelines exist to inform practice. This study examined the perceptions of outpatients and their support persons regarding what constitutes optimal care for people with brain cancer presenting to the ED.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A cross sectional descriptive survey study was undertaken. Participants included adults attending hospital outpatient clinics (n ​= ​181, 60% of eligible participants). Participants completed a survey assessing perceptions of optimal care for brain cancer patients presenting to emergency department and socio-demographic characteristics.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The survey items endorsed as ‘essential’ by participants included that the emergency department team help patients: ‘understand signs and symptoms to watch out for’ (51%); ‘understand the next steps in care and why’ (48%); ‘understand if their medical condition suggests it is likely they will die in hospital’ (47%); ‘ask patients if they have a substitute decision maker and want that person told they are in the emergency department’ (44%); ‘understand the purpose of tests and procedures’ (41%).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Symptom management, effective communication and supported decision-making should be prioritised by ED teams. Further research to establish the views of those affected by brain cancer about essential care delivered in the ED setting, and to compare these views with the quality of care that is actually delivered, is warranted.

sec.title: Brain cancer causes significant burden for patients, their support persons and the healthcare system
sec.p: In 2018, there were an estimated 296,851 incident (ie, new) cases of brain and Central Nervous System (CNS) cancers, and 243,037 deaths across 185 countries.1 Despite the relatively low incidence and prevalence compared to other types of cancer, such as breast cancer (over 2million new cases worldwide),1 brain cancer imposes a significant burden on patients, families and the health system.2, 3, 4, 5 The five-year survival rate for brain cancer is 22% which is significantly lower than other types of cancer such as prostate (95%), melanoma (92%) and female breast (91%).6 Brain cancer is associated with significant economic costs to the patient and the health system, including direct and indirect costs and out-of-pocket costs.7, 8, 9, 10, 11 Brain cancer is often characterised by rapid progression and significant cognitive and behavioural changes.4,12,13 Practical and social issues, such as losing the ability to drive, loss of income and changes in relationships, may lead to a feeling of being a burden and loss of independence.14,15 The consequence of a diagnosis of brain cancer, its symptoms and treatment are also often experienced by support persons, including family members and/or carers.3,4,16 Carers of people with brain cancer report higher levels of strain and lower physical and mental wellbeing compared to those of other cancer patients.3,17,18

sec.title: People with brain cancer commonly present to emergency departments
sec.p: There are over 8.4 million attendances by Australians managed by emergency departments (EDs) every year.19 People typically present to EDs following unexpected illness or injury any time of the night or day; and the duration of visits is often short, requiring rapid as well as appropriate clinical decisions.20 People with cancer commonly present to the ED to manage concerns associated with their diagnosis or treatment.20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25 The primary reasons for ED visits by people with cancer include fever, infection, gastrointestinal toxicities, pain, respiratory symptoms and bleeding.24,26 For people with brain cancer, ED visits may be related to the cancer, complications of the cancer treatment or something that is unrelated to cancer.26,27 EDs are also a common place for diagnosis of adult brain tumours.28 People with brain cancer typically present to ED after their cancer diagnosis, with some patients returning to the ED multiple times.25 They are also more likely to visit the ED in the year following their diagnosis than other people with cancer.26 In New South Wales (NSW), 40% of people visited the ED in the year after their diagnosis and 47% visited the ED in the last 30 days of their life.26 Patients who present to an ED during their cancer treatment are more likely to be admitted to hospital rather than discharged home, and this occurs more commonly for people with brain cancer.26 In one of the few Australian studies published to date, 54% of patients with primary malignant glioma received ED care in the 120 days prior to their death, and 40% of those who died in hospital were admitted via the ED.28 Up to 25% of patients with malignant glioma will die in an acute hospital bed.28

sec.title: Lack of knowledge on the needs of brain cancer patients presenting to EDs and areas for improvements in the quality of care
sec.p: Patients and their families are often stressed, and their level of stress can increase as they arrive in the high intensity ED environment.29,30 Additional stressors in an already difficult situation, such as lengthy waiting times, unanticipated procedures and nursing and medical staff that they do not know can compound the stress of their ED visit.31 Poor communication between staff, patients and families, can compromise patient outcomes.31,32 While visiting the ED may be appropriate to assess and manage unexpected or acute onset concerns, some ED visits may be preventable with adequate management of symptoms and treatment-related toxicities, appropriate care coordination including planned admissions to hospital.33,34 This requires a collaborative, interprofessional approach to care highlighting the need for effective teamwork of specialists working in oncology, emergency medicine and other areas, such as neurology and general practice.35 To achieve this, effective communication and collaboration within multidisciplinary teams of healthcare professionals is required, including physicians, nurses and administrative staff working in inpatient and outpatient clinics.36 They need to work together (both informally and formally) and understand each other roles in order to meet patients’ healthcare needs.37 Such interprofessional communication and collaboration may improve a number of outcomes, including increased patient adherence to prescribed care, improved patient satisfaction, and reduced fragmentation of care and medical errors.36,38,39 However, integration across the interface of care between specialist cancer services, general practice and ED can be challenging. With highly complex patients that are not regularly seen in the ED, staff may be less familiar with immune-compromise and chemotherapy side effects such as nausea, vomiting, mucositis and diarrhoea.40 After an ED visit, patients with CNS cancers are known to have poorer outcomes than those who do not, with long hospital admissions, treatment dose reductions and treatment delays.20,21 Greater understanding of the clinical needs of brain cancer patients presenting to EDs, and identification of areas for improvements in the quality of care delivered to these patients, is warranted.23

sec.title: How this study will help understand what constitutes optimal care for people diagnosed with brain cancer presenting to EDs
sec.p: Patient and public involvement is recognized as a key component of developing and implementing evidence-based models of care.41 As optimal care depends not only on individual disease characteristics but also on health status and personal preferences,7 definitions of optimal care should be guided by representative and credible data from consumers, rather than clinician opinion alone. Most indicators of ED performance focus on outcomes, such as time to receiving care, time to discharge from ED, and readmission or representation rates.42,43 While patients are surveyed about their ED experience, these do not focus on consumer perspectives of what optimal care should look like for different patient groups, or specifically about care that is delivered to people diagnosed with brain cancer. Currently, what constitutes optimal care for people diagnosed with brain cancer is largely derived from research in other tumour groups, clinicians’ perceptions and opinion, or qualitative explorations with small samples of patients and/or family members that may not be generalisable to the broader population.3,5,15,44,45 Therefore, this study represented a first step in a program of work aimed at establishing consumer perceptions of optimal care in the ED. Specifically, this study examined the perceptions of a sample of outpatients and their accompanying support persons regarding what constitutes optimal care for people with brain cancer presenting to ED.

sec.title: Design and setting
sec.p: A cross sectional, descriptive survey study was conducted in outpatient clinics at a major regional hospital in Australia. Outpatient clinics included respiratory, immunology, neurology, cardiology, gastroenterology, orthopaedics, rehabilitation and general surgery.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p: Individuals were eligible to participate if they: were aged at least 18 years; were a patient attending an appointment at one of the outpatient clinics or any support person (ie, family member, friend and/or carer) accompanying a patient to an appointment; had sufficient English to complete the survey; and were mentally and physically well enough to participate.

sec.title: Recruitment and data collection
sec.p: A trained Research Assistant (RA) approached patients and their accompanying support persons in the clinic waiting room prior to their appointment, and provided them with written and verbal information about the study. The RA confirmed eligibility, and invited them to take part in the study. Consenting participants completed a survey on touch screen computer while they waited for their appointment. Assistance was provided where needed to use the touch screen computer. Age group and gender of non-consenting individuals were collected.

sec.title: Development of the survey
sec.p: At the time of data collection, no psychometrically robust self-report measures were available that included an assessment of optimal care for brain cancer patients across the care pathway. Therefore, a study-specific survey was developed using the following process: First, brain cancer patients (n ​= ​13) and their support persons (n ​= ​13) participated in 30-min individual interviews to elicit their views and experiences in relation to brain cancer care. This included a discussion of their diagnosis, treatment, and experiences with different access points to the health system across the cancer care continuum (ie, primary care, specialist/treatment phase, emergency department, and community and/or specialist inpatient palliative care). The list of items was then derived from participant responses within four broad care domains, including: (1) initial diagnosis and consideration of treatment options, (2) care during the treatment phase, (3) care provided by emergency and other healthcare professionals and (4) end-of-life care. Additional domains and items were derived from reviews of recommendations made in available cancer and end-of-life care consensus guidelines and policy documents in Australia and internationally.46, 47, 48, 49, 50 The full list of potential items was then reviewed by a panel including an emergency physician, an oncologist, a surgeon, a brain cancer care coordinator and behavioural scientists until consensus (at least 75% agreement) on content and format of items (eg, clinical relevance, acceptability, clarity) was reached. Items were then pilot tested with a convenience sample of 10 patients for acceptability, relevance and clarity, and wording was refined based on their feedback.

Optimal care in the ED. Participants were presented with the following statement: “Imagine a patient with brain cancer is visiting the emergency department (ED) of a hospital for a problem related to the disease. For example: they may be in pain, short of breath, or have had a seizure.”

Participants were then asked to rate the level of importance of the ED team helping patients to understand: (1) what the next steps in care might be and why (eg, hospital stay, go home); (2) the purpose of any tests or procedures they will have; (3) unexpected problems they might face if they stay in hospital, such as falls, infection; (4) if their medical condition suggests it is likely they may die in hospital; (5) whether their GP or regular treating team will be notified of their ED visit; (6) when to contact their GP or regular treating team for follow up after going home; (7) when they will be able to resume their usual activities; (8) signs or symptoms to watch for to prevent another visit. Participants were also asked to indicate the level of importance of the ED team asking patients if they have: (9) written down their wishes for future care; and (10) a substitute decision maker (ie, someone to make decisions on patient's behalf if they are unable to make decisions themselves) and want that person told they are in the ED. For each item, participants selected one response from the following options including: “not at all”, “slightly important”, “moderately important”, and “very important and essential”.

Sociodemographic characteristics: Participants also provided their gender, age, highest level of education and whether they knew anyone who had been diagnosed with brain cancer (self, spouse, other family, child, or other).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: All statistical analyses were conducted using IBM SPSS Statistics for Windows (Version 25.0. Armonk, NY: IBM Corp.). Means and standard deviations (SDs) and frequencies and proportions were calculated for each of the items. The items were then ranked according to the proportion of participants who rated the item as ‘essential’. Chi square analyses were conducted to compare the proportion of participants who rated items as ‘essential’ for those who reported that they know someone who has been diagnosed with brain cancer (n ​= ​89) compared to those participants who reported they did not know someone who has been diagnosed with brain cancer (n ​= ​92).

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: The study received ethics approval from the Hunter New England Research Ethics and Governance Committee, and the University of Newcastle Human Research Ethics Committee (IRB No. 16/10/19/4.12). All methods were performed in accordance with the Declarations of Helsinki.

sec.title: Sample
sec.p:
A total of 351 people were approached to participate, of whom 27 were deemed ineligible (too unwell n ​= ​6, non-English speaking n ​= ​2, hearing problems n ​= ​5, already completed n ​= ​3, cognitive impairment n ​= ​1, distressed n ​= ​6, not reported n ​= ​4). Of the 324 remaining, 195 consented to the study (60% of those eligible) and completed at least part of the larger survey, however only 181 attempted the ED-related items and were included in the final analysis for this paper. sec.title: Optimal care ratings
sec.p:
Fig. 1 presents the proportion of participants who rated the component of care as either ‘very important’ or ‘essential’. The top five items endorsed as ‘essential’ components of care by the highest number of participants were that the ED team: ‘help patients understand signs and symptoms to watch out for’ (51%); ‘help patients understand the next steps in care and why’ (48%); ‘help patients understand if their medical condition suggests it is likely they will die in hospital’ (47%); ‘ask patients if they have a substitute decision maker and want that person told they are in the emergency department’ (44%) and ‘help patients understand the purpose of tests and procedures’ (41%). All items were rated as either ‘very important’ or ‘essential’ by at least 76% of participants.Fig. 1

Table 2 presents the ratings of importance for each of the component of care for the whole sample, then according to those who reported knowing someone with brain cancer and those who reported not knowing someone with brain cancer. No significant differences in the proportion of participants rating a component of care as ‘essential’ were reported between those participants who knew someone with brain cancer (n ​= ​89) compared to those who did not know someone with brain cancer (n ​= ​95) (P ​> ​0.05 for all comparisons).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This is one of the first Australian studies to examine the perceptions of patients and their support persons attending outpatient clinics regarding the essential components and processes of optimal care delivered to people diagnosed with brain cancer when presenting to emergency departments (EDs). All of the items were rated by a majority of participants (> 76%) as either ‘very important’ or ‘essential’. Participants perceived the most important components of care delivered to people with brain cancer and their families in the ED setting related to effective symptom management, communication and supported decision-making.

Helping patients understand signs and symptoms to watch out for to prevent another ED visits was judged as the most essential item by participants in this study. Cancer patients experience a range of symptoms that may prompt ED visits, including pain, nausea, fever, fatigue and shortness of breath.20,22 In addition to these generalised symptoms, brain cancer patients may also present with symptoms related to neurological deterioration, such as seizures, headaches and focal neurologic deficits.5 Our findings support patients' wish to be involved in their care and receive guidance on how to recognise, treat and manage their disease and symptoms. Ensuring effective communication with patients about symptom management has been identified as a key strategy for reducing unplanned acute care for cancer patients.51 This information can help patients and families to develop skills in self-care and caring tasks, including symptom management, and improve compliance with recommendations.2 Despite this, information needs are not consistently met by health services,2,33 with suboptimal information about symptom management a common source of dissatisfaction among brain cancer patients and their families.52,53 ED visits present an additional opportunity to evaluate patients’ symptom management knowledge and behaviours,5 which when paired with appropriate referrals to outpatient and home-based supports52 that should ideally happen as part of usual care coordination, may prevent future avoidable ED visits.

‘Helping patients understand the next steps in care and why’ and ‘helping patients understand the purpose of any tests and procedures’ was also rated as essential by many participants. New South Wales (NSW) Emergency Department patient surveys support these findings, with 95% of all ED patients saying that they need information on how to manage their care at home.26 Information about treatment plans are critical if patients and families are able to understand their condition,54 play an active role in care decisions and manage adverse consequences of disease and its treatment.55 The quality, nature and accessibility of information often varies according to the skills, time and personal preferences of individual healthcare providers.14,56 Inadequacies in involvement in decision-making and information provision are common in brain cancer care.14,15,57 The ability to process and retain information may be further impeded by neurological and cognitive deficits common among primary brain cancer patients.2 While it is acknowledged that information should be consistent, accessible, and presented in a way that maximises the probability that it is understood and remembered, there remains a degree of uncertainty about the most effective approach for brain cancer patients and families.2 While less critical than other aspects of care, “helping patients understand when they will be able to resume their usual activities' is still also viewed as an important role for the ED team. As people are in a crisis situation, thoughts about returning to usual activities may be less relevant at that time.58,59 A similar pattern emerged for items: ‘helping patients understand whether their GP treating team will be notified of their visit’ and ‘unexpected problems they may face if they stay in hospital’.

‘Asking patients if they have a substitute decision maker and want that person told they are in the ED’ should also be considered by the ED team when treating brain cancer patients. About half of patients with cancer will visit an ED in the last 30 days of their life.26 Given the uncertain prognosis, associated cognitive decline and often non-curative nature of brain cancer,44,60 early conversations about advance care planning (ACP) and end-of-life care are particularly relevant.61,62 When patients arrive in ED alone, without capacity and no advocate, a well-written ACP allows clinicians to provide care in accordance with patients' wishes. However, there is little research available to guide advance care planning practice.62 Further, a range of barriers to ACP activities in the ED, including discussion and documentation of goals-of-care, have been identified. These include the ED environment, time, patient acuity and expectations, family dynamics and difficulty accessing complete medical histories.63 While busy EDs may not be the ideal setting for introducing ACP, our findings do highlight the importance of ED staff identifying whether a person has a substitute decision maker. Legal frameworks in some Australian States require practitioners to “make reasonable efforts” to find out whether a patient has an advance care directive or appointed a substitute-decision maker.64 Efforts to improve communication between ED staff, GPs and treating teams, as well as ensuring that ACP documentation accompanies patients to the ED, are promising areas for future intervention.

The item ‘helping patients understand if their medical condition suggests that they may die in hospital’ was also rated as ‘essential’ by many participants (47%). It is important to acknowledge that palliative care and emergency care are not mutually exclusive. If symptoms cannot be controlled in the community or emergent investigations or procedures are required, the ED is a trusted place that is available 24 ​h a day, 7 days a week to relieve suffering.65 EDs are a common point of contact for patients in the last year of life,65,66 however, the ability of ED staff to accurately predict short-term mortality may be compromised by a lack of validated risk stratification instruments,67 as well as the time, skills and knowledge of the individual clinician.65,68 Even when the prognosis is known and patients and families indicate a preference for receiving this information; it is not consistently communicated by clinicians.65 ED staff have expressed a desire for further education and training in end-of-life communication and issues.68 Tools such as the SPICT69 and the more recent CriSTAL checklist67 as well as measures for frailty in older people, such as the Clinical Frailty Scale,70 have also been developed in an effort to reduce prognostic uncertainty and prompt conversations to support clinical decisions about death and dying in acute care settings.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The findings of this study should be considered in light of several limitations. Firstly, like many studies in this field, this study was conducted in outpatient clinics within one regional hospital in NSW, which limits the generalisability of these findings. The sample surveyed was also a heterogeneous group of health service consumers and their support persons. While 40% of the sample reported knowing someone who diagnosed with brain cancer, their knowledge and experience in relation to brain cancer care is likely to vary which may have influenced ratings. Low response rates were likely due to some patients being called into appointments, or the nature of the topic. These rates may mean that the responses may not be representative of the outpatient population sampled in this study. Formal psychometric testing of the investigator developed surveys should be undertaken during the next phase of the research program. Also, choices about a hypothetical situation (ie, “people diagnosed with brain cancer”) do not necessarily translate to a real situation faced in the future (ie, by those actually diagnosed or caring for someone with brain cancer). While we did not identify any significant statistical differences between those reporting knowing someone with brain cancer compared to those who did not, replicating the survey with people diagnosed with brain cancer and their support persons, particularly those who are at a point late in the illness trajectory, would help determine whether views differ for those who are actually receiving this type of care. While this approach faces ethical challenges in confronting patients with issues they may not wish to consider, obtaining patients' views on end-of-life care in particular has been recognized as an essential component of ‘good’ research practice. Planning for serious illness and high quality end-of-life is greatly valued by the majority of the general public.71 Replicating the survey with people recruited from different care settings and from culturally and linguistically diverse groups could also help to determine potential disparities in views.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Consumers perceive the provision of information about treatment plans, symptom management and prognosis as essential components of care delivered to brain cancer patients in emergency departments. Identification and involvement of formally appointed substitute decision makers is also judged as essential component of care for this patient group. Future research should further establish brain cancer patient and support person perceptions about what constitutes optimal cancer care delivered in emergency departments, and compare this with the care received to highlight deficiencies and to identify opportunities for improvement.
